channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [AMQP-510] Direct Reply-To requires separate connection
item.description:
We are using an older version of Spring AMQP so perhaps this is irrelevant but it appears that you can not RPC (sendAndReceive) with the same connection factory using direct reply-to (I backported AMQP-448 using template.execute(...)) . If you do it will sporadically fail and drop messages.

That is it appears you cannot send a message with direct reply-to and then respond to that message with the same connection factory (because it will reuse the same connection).

Some may not have seen this as this requires sending large volumes of messages to the same machine which is probably not the case in production (ie request reply to yourself is not a common use case).

I'm somewhat sure this is applicable with the latest version (I can't test yet but looking at the code it appears so). I'm not sure if this is an inherent bug/limitation with the rabbitmq client connections or if its in spring amqp's connection factory.

I couldn't decide where to post this as this probably not a bug but perhaps should be included in the documentation or maybe I'm just wrong?

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Please show what you mean by

(I backported AMQP-448 using template.execute(...))

(point me to your code).

The single connection is irrelevant. The direct reply-to is associated with the channel - when you consume from the "special" queue name, the broker sets up a special route back to that consumer. Take a look at the replyTo header on the server side and you'll see the unique name for each replyTo.

If you are doing it entirely within the execute() method, you are not really using Spring-AMQP at that point (aside from the shared connection); you are using the rabbit client API directly.

So, this may be an issue we need to raise with the rabbitmq guys.

One thing you might have missed in your "backport" is that the actual replyTo (on the server side), might include / characters because it's base64.

This needed changes in the MessageListenerAdapter to properly interpret the reply.

Notice how the Address object has extra code to decode these replyTo addresses.

Without such code, the replies will be dropped by the server.

I suggest you try with 1.4.5.

It appears the MessageListenerAdapter/Address could be the problem! Thank you.

Although I'm not sure why having separate connections causes this to never happen (ie reply-tos without "/").

It is strange though because our rather old Message Listener Adapter shows it decoding correctly but messages with "/" are indeed the ones it gets stuck on:

reply-to: amq.rabbitmq.reply-to.g2dkABNyYWJiaXRAYWdlbnQtbGFwdG9wAAA8fQAAAAkC./N6eV/ciSXcScyfBVo5kdg==
toString(): direct:///amq.rabbitmq.reply-to.g2dkABNyYWJiaXRAYWdlbnQtbGFwdG9wAAA8fQAAAAkC./N6eV/ciSXcScyfBVo5kdg==
getExchangeName():
getRoutingName(): amq.rabbitmq.reply-to.g2dkABNyYWJiaXRAYWdlbnQtbGFwdG9wAAA8fQAAAAkC./N6eV/ciSXcScyfBVo5kdg==

The only time I got it to make "/" in the reply to was by reusing the connection.

Here is our backported code.

	protected ListenableFuture<Message> doSendAndReceiveWithFastReplyTo(
 
    protected ListenableFuture<Message> doSendAndReceiveWithFastReplyTo(
 
            final String exchange, 
            final String routingKey, 
            final Message message) {
 
        final RabbitTemplate rt = ((RabbitTemplate)nonTxAmqpTemplate);
 
        
        SettableFuture<Message> replyMessage = rt.execute(new ChannelCallback<SettableFuture<Message>>() {
 
            public SettableFuture<Message> doInRabbit(final Channel channel) throws Exception {
 
                final SettableFuture<Message> future = SettableFuture.create();
 
                //final ArrayBlockingQueue<Message> replyHandoff = new ArrayBlockingQueue<Message>(1);
 
 
 
                Assert.isNull(message.getMessageProperties().getReplyTo(),
 
                        "Send-and-receive methods can only be used if the Message does not already have a replyTo property.");
 
//                DeclareOk queueDeclaration = channel.queueDeclare();
 
//                String replyTo = queueDeclaration.getQueue();
 
                final String replyTo = AMQ_RABBITMQ_REPLY_TO;
 
                message.getMessageProperties().setReplyTo(replyTo);
 
 
 
 
 
                final String consumerTag = UUID.randomUUID().toString();
 
 
 
                final Reference<TimerListener> timer = (replyTimeout < 0) ? null : ThreadTimer.getInstance().addTimerListener(new TimerListener() {
 
                    @Override
 
                    public void tick() {
 
                        if (! future.cancel(false))  {
 
                            try {
 
                                channel.basicCancel(consumerTag);
 
                            }
 
                            catch (IOException e) {
 
                            }
 
                        }
 
                    }
 
                    
                    @Override
 
                    public int getIntervalTimeInMilliseconds() {
 
                        return (int) replyTimeout + 100;
 
                    }
 
                });
 
 
 
                final DefaultConsumer consumer = new DefaultConsumer(channel) {
 
                    @Override
 
                    public void handleDelivery(String consumerTag, Envelope envelope, AMQP.BasicProperties properties,
 
                            byte[] body) throws IOException {
 
                        MessageProperties messageProperties = messagePropertiesConverter.toMessageProperties(
 
                                properties, envelope, "UTF-8");
 
                        Message reply = new Message(body, messageProperties);
 
//                        if (log.isInfoEnabled()) {
 
//                            log.info("Message received " + reply);
 
//                        }
 
 
 
                        future.set(reply);
 
                        //replyHandoff.put(reply);
 
                        try {
 
                            channel.basicCancel(consumerTag);
 
                        }
 
                        catch (Exception e) {
 
                        }
 
                        if (timer != null)
 
                            timer.clear();
 
 
 
                    }
 
                };
 
                final boolean noAck = true;
 
                final boolean noLocal = true;
 
                final boolean exclusive = true;
 
                channel.basicConsume(replyTo, noAck, consumerTag, noLocal, exclusive, null, consumer);
 
                doSend(channel, exchange, routingKey, message, null);
 
//                Message reply = (replyTimeout < 0) ? replyHandoff.take() : replyHandoff.poll(replyTimeout,
 
//                        TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
 
                //channel.basicCancel(consumerTag);
 
                //return reply;
 
                return future;
 
            }
 
        });
 
        return replyMessage;
 
    }

The backported code uses a SettableFuture instead of queue (you'll have to trust me that this is not causing the issue). BTW the SettableFuture appears to be much faster than the blocking queue.

The reason we can't use Spring AMQP latest is because it relies on Spring 4. We are still on Spring 3 and had some issues making that big of a jump.

Interesting; yes, the issue with the / was because we made the direct:// part optional in 1.4.0 and this caused any / in the reply queue name cause us to break it into two.

So, with the 1.3.x Address, the pattern doesn't match and the whole string is treated as the queue name.

I don't know the algorithm that rabbitmq uses to generate the name, but it seems to me it will be possible to get a / regardless of the connection.

However, it still doesn't explain why such replies are dropped.

I think the next step will be to try to reproduce using the amqp-client directly (outside of Spring AMQP) so we can eliminate rabbitmq itself as the root cause.

FYI, I wrote a test case using both the raw client API and Spring AMQP; I ran it against 1.3.9.RELEASE with no problems.

BTW, as I would have expected, I see random / in the replyTo, even when using different connections.
Closing; please request reopening if you still feel there's a problem with the framework.
